segments.text: OK, this is Ron Schorn about to interview Wes Traub.
Wes, count down from 10 or something.
OK, this is Thursday, April 22, 1983.
And this is Ron Schorn interviewing Wes Traub at the Center for Astrophysics here in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
OK, Wes, your name is?
Wesley Traub.
And when were you born?
Where?
Wisconsin, Milwaukee.
How did you first get interested in astronomy?
Oh, well, I guess I was interested in astronomy like most kids.
It's just interesting.
But the thing that really interested me, I remember when I was a teenager, was
spectroscopy, strangely enough.
I mean, the idea of being able to measure the property of something that was far away by looking at the spectra, you know, Fraunhofer lines and all that sort of stuff.
How did you learn about that?
Book in the library, go to the Adler Planetarium or what?
Well, we didn't have any planetariums, planetaria.
It must have been from books, yeah.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
I went to the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee for...
Undergraduate four years.
Your major was?
Physics.
Actually, the physics, the major was complicated.
It was called Applied Math and Engineering Physics.
But it was basically lots of math and physics.
And it was great because I didn't have to take any other courses.
I didn't have to take any languages, hardly any English.
I could take math courses all day.
Where did you go to grad school?
I went to the University of Wisconsin at Madison, the physics department.
And I...
was lucky enough then to meet up with Julian Mack, who was a
a spectroscopist working on atomic spectroscopy, and was someone who was present in the late 20s and early 30s for the beginning of quantum mechanics.
And near the end of his career, he was my professor at Wisconsin.
So the stuff that I kind of liked, I just sort of lucked into at Madison.
At that time, were you thinking of becoming an astronomer or were you going to be a physicist?
Oh, no.
What I was going to do then was to go into business with my father, who ran a lumber company, because I didn't know that people did this for a living.
By the way, what year did you get your bachelor's and what year did you get your Ph.D.?
Okay, bachelor's degree was in 1962, and Ph.D. was in 68, in physics.
What was your dissertation on, by the way?
Our thesis was on the abundance of lithium in sunspots.
This was in the physics department, but the astronomy department was right upstairs, and so there was communication.
a piece of equipment that had been invented at Wisconsin called a Pepsios interferometer.

This was made up out of three Fabry-Perot interferometers put in series so that the light would come through each one of them, one after the other, and selectively isolate narrower and narrower bands of light
Then you would scan the instrument from one wavelength to another by changing the air pressure in between the plates of the Fabry-Perot's.
This is a wonderful instrument because it had all of the tendue, the light collecting power area and solid angle product of Fabry-Perot's.

which meant that for astronomy, you could put a circular object at the entrance, not a slit, but a round aperture, like a star or a planet or the sun, part of the sun, and get all the light through the instrument at very high resolution.
It had spectral resolutions of 500,000 to a million in that range.
When you finished your PhD, where did you get your first job and why?
I got my first and last job here at the Smithsonian.
And the connection was that while I was working on my thesis, there was Nat Carlton out here at the Smithsonian who had been working in the physics department

at Harvard and also interested in Earth's upper atmospheric properties, became interested in planetary atmospheres early in his career by transitioning from the Earth's upper atmosphere to planetary atmospheres.
And this was in the days before.
well, 1968.
It was in the days before much was known about abundances in planetary atmospheres.
And in particular, the problem that he noticed was that the atmosphere of Mars was not well characterized.
The pressures on Mars were
postulated to be anywhere over a range of about 1,000 in surface pressure, and there just simply were no measurements that were highly reliable.

And it was his thought, his idea, that this Pepsios interferometer could be used in the near-infrared, around 1 micron, to look at absorption lines of CO2 in the Martian atmosphere, and we could measure the abundance of CO2 that way.
So while I was a graduate student, I came out here to the Smithsonian and helped set up and invent some of the materials for a pepsiose to be used in the near-infrared.
And that experiment was set up at the Agassiz telescope, 61-inch telescope in Harvard, Mass.
And the experiment was run simultaneously while I was a graduate student.
We learned how to focus this thing in the infrared.
and get it to measure the absorption lines on Mars.
Who paid your bills at that time?
Was it NASA?
This was a NASA grant from, I think, yeah, from Planetary.
I'd have to look back.
Yeah, it was a bill.
Bill Brunk was the person that we dealt with then, yeah, and for several years thereafter.
Had Nat gotten this grant started before you came on board?
It was about simultaneous.
He got the money about the same time I came, and the grant was to pay for me to come here and to do this work, to buy the equipment.
Yes?
What about the, you mentioned the planetary atmospheres, not too much was known about them that you could really count on.
Let's say the nose cone people, the reentry vehicle people could really take the hard stuff.
Right, yeah.
I mean, the issue here, excuse me, I should have said, the issue about Mars was a probe was to be sent there, and the question was, do you need a reentry vehicle?
Could you use a parachute?
How do you get something down to the surface of the planet?
And so you wanted to know what the pressure was.
That was the immediate practical problem.
Go ahead, yeah.
What about the state of the art of planetary astronomy in general when you came in?
Was it pretty anti-Diluvian, pretty primitive compared to now?
Well, there was a remarkable amount that was not known.
I hadn't worked in planetary astronomy before this.
physics laboratories doing atomic spectroscopy.
And the sun was my major experience outside the laboratory.
So I learned about planetary atmospheres.
And so it didn't seem ancient to me or outmoded.
It just seemed like what was.
You always think that things are the way they are.
You don't think, my god, why don't people know any better?
These were hard experiments to do.
And so to us, it was obvious then that nobody could have done a better experiment before.
How many different major NASA contracts have you had?
Not every year, but, you know, we worked on Pepsi Olsen, then we did this and stuff like that.
Oh, a few, maybe four or five.
The major ones that I remember are that we worked on this one grant, which extended for six, seven years, something like that, to work on planetary atmospheres.
And we worked on many, many different aspects of planetary atmospheres and branched out and did things like interstellar lines and a lot of other stuff from that base.
And actually, my planetary experience extends from...
The first published paper was in 72, and the last one really was in 79.
So that was the period in which we were using that grant to work.
And after that, I became more interested in infrared and other things, and I started
Working with other NASA grants for other purposes.
Run out of planets?
There's plenty of stars.
Well, actually, I moved from doing that to doing far infrared spectroscopy with a Fourier transform spectrometer.
And part of the reason, well, this is getting ahead of the story, but we went to Bill Brunk.
I mean, that was the start of my independent research work.
noticed that there was a lack of measurement in the far infrared, around 100 micron wavelength, because that part of the atmosphere is totally absorbing due to water vapor, rotational absorptions.
And there was, at the time, here at the Smithsonian, a dramatic experiment that Giovanni Fazio had been running for a few years.
This was a one-meter diameter telescope that was carried to about 28 kilometers altitude by large balloons, helium-filled balloons from Palestine, Texas.
And the thought here was, gee, why don't we build an instrument to look at spectral lines?
Because all that was being done then was filters, broadband photometric measurements of planets, among other things, too.
Outer planets we looked at with that instrument.
But I was interested in looking at the spectra.
And so we proposed to the Planetary Division, to Bill Brunk, in fact,
to build an FTS to go onto this instrument.

And one of the things, we had a number of things that were of interest, but one of the things was to look at the atmospheres of Venus and Mars and see there was a whole number of rotational lines in the far infrared that we should be able to see there.
We did receive the money.
I received the grant, $150,000 to build this instrument.
And we built it and flew it.
It turned out to be a very difficult thing to do to point this telescope accurately.
And so, in fact, we never ever did use it to record any planetary spectra.
But we went on to look at the Earth's atmosphere.
And my career on atmospheres has evolved into the Earth's atmosphere then.
And we've done a lot of work since then on the terrestrial atmosphere.
But that's not planets.
That's the Earth.
Oh, may I continue on this?
Yeah, it just occurred to me that as an interesting sidelight, my interest in planets has followed my other interests, which are spectroscopy, but really interferometry.
I just am fascinated by the idea of interfering beams of light.
And another experiment that I've worked on for the last decade is
using high angular resolution separated telescopes to look at stars and materials around stars perhaps.
And so an instrument that we have now built on Mount Hopkins uses telescopes that are separated by up to about 38 meters to do a modern Michelson stellar interferometer type experiment.

And one of the things that we've been looking at recently is, can this instrument detect planets around other stars by looking at the very small wobble that you would see in the position of the star as it moves across the sky?
It's an incredibly difficult problem, but it comes back to searching for planets instead of looking at ones that you know, and that kind of amuses me.
What wavelength is the uranoprometer after wavelengths?
The one at Mount Hopkins.
The Mount Hopkins instrument.
This would be a visible and near-infrared instrument, visible and K-band instrument.
How was your relationship with NASA when they were funding?
Who's funding you now, by the way, NSF or?
We have a little money through the University of Wyoming from the NSF for this project.
interferometer project, which is called IOTA for Infrared Optical Telescope Array on Mount Hopkins.
And there is some other funding for that project from NASA also, and internally from the Smithsonian.
But the bulk of my funding is for looking at the Earth's atmosphere, because I run these two sorts of projects parallel, or run with them.
And the bulk of the funding is from
the upper atmospheric division at NASA to look at the Earth's atmosphere.
How would you say NASA does when they're giving you money?
Do they butt in?
Are they getting worse?
Are they getting better?
Do they generally let you do what you said you were going to do, or what?
Feel free.
No, I have nothing but happiness to report on that.
I mean, every experiment that I've been involved with in the planetary division and in the upper atmospheric division, we've proposed to do work.
NASA has almost always given us essentially all of the money that we've asked for.
I can't recall a single case where somebody has come and said, you ought to be doing this and not that.
And on top of that, after you do the work,

I haven't, nobody's ever come back and said, well, you promised to do X, Y, and Z, but you only did X and half of Y because, you know, you always end up sort of thinking you can do more than you actually do, and sometimes you do things that you never thought you would do.
So it always amazes me that people never come along and inventory what you put in your first proposal and see whether or not that's what you actually reported three years later.
It's astonishing.
I hope they don't start doing it.
There was a comment that I read somewhere that...
By definition, of course, discoveries cannot be foreseen because someone had been accused by some government agency of not foreseeing this discovery.
Yes, of course, that's ridiculous.
You know, some people object to having to write proposals and say, oh, well, this is a lot of busy work.
I think it's a good idea because it helps you clearly formulate your ideas.
You think of things that you might not have thought about when you're forced to write it down and defend it in front of people.
And so I don't have any problem with that.
What do you consider the most important piece of work you've done in planetary astronomy?
Oh, there are several things that really excited me when I looked at them.
The first experiment I did was to discover oxygen on Mars.
And this was a big thrill because I'd only discovered one other thing once before in a laboratory setting.
And to go out and actually look through a telescope and discover a molecule that nobody had ever seen before was really
a very exciting thing for me.
And that was 1972 we published that.
That was a follow-up of the work that had been done on CO2 on Mars.
And so I always remember that fondly, perhaps because it was the first thing.
I don't know if it was the most important, but it certainly was fun for me.
Okay, that was my next question, what was the most fun, and you just answered it.
Did you ever...
run into any real bogs or morasses or blind alleys or things where you said, oh, we never should have tried this or something like that?
Well, there was a whole body of work that we did on looking at Jupiter and Saturn in lines of methane, ammonia, methane and ammonia, and hydrogen lines also.
And I guess I have a regret.
I mean, it was a morass in the sense that we took a ton of data on spectral lines that were not well characterized.
We didn't know what the temperature dependence of their oscillator strengths was.
But we did it in the hope that these things would be learned later.

Nat Carlton and I spent many, many, many nights at the 60-inch telescope on Mount Hopkins that he actually built, and I helped him with a little bit in those days, taking data on these outer planets that never really ended up being digested and published in the kind of form that I would have been happy with.
There are a few reports out, but we saw a lot of things, like ammonia coming and going, and many, many things that never really quite got
tidied up the way they should have been and published.
How have NASA's dollars affected planetary astronomy in general?
Well, I'm not sure how to answer that, because I actually... Where would we be without it?
Oh, well, unquestionably, none of this stuff would ever have been done at this level if there wasn't funding from NASA to do it.
I mean, I would have gone off to work for IBM or something like that.
Well, in fact, that was my other promising offer.
Instead of coming to a much lower-paying job here at the Smithsonian, doing something that sounded like a lot of fun.
So if it were not for the NASA support, we would know none of this stuff, I think, now.
Back when you started, were you aware of any...

snobbishness on the part of quote real unquote astronomers towards people who worked on the planets oh well yes uh i mean i i'm even more aware of uh of this well we were talking about second class status for planetary astronomers you said you were even more aware of that well well the thing is i i was a physicist i am a physicist and i came from the physics department and
I learned a little astronomy by going up and taking a few courses and reading books, but I wasn't a real astronomer.
And there are real astronomers and there are outsiders.
So I'm perfectly aware of the fact that real astronomers are different than people who get into the field by some other back door, like studying physics.
And planetary astronomy is one of those
outside of real astronomy areas also.
But at the Smithsonian here, we're all coexisting quite happily, and I've never really had any problems with it.
I enjoy what I'm doing, and other people, I think, respect what we're doing.
Do you think over the last 30 years or so that the planetary astronomers have managed to get up to about equal status with the stellar and galactic people?
Well, it...
No, I don't think that that's ever the case.

I mean, if you study galaxies and what the distribution of galaxies is, like some of the people in this building do, you will always attract much more attention and be considered to be a real astronomer by the general public than if you study planets.

I think there's certainly such a great interest in the part of the general public in planets because that's where people live and there might be life that this is, you know, one doesn't feel like, I don't feel like a second class citizen having done this sort of thing.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job publicizing themselves to the general public?
I think that the best publicist in the world for astronomy was a planetary astronomer.
Carl Sagan, in my opinion, did a wonderful job publicizing the adventure of astronomy and, of course, of planetary astronomy and science in general.
I don't think he's appreciated by a lot of other astronomers or maybe even planetary astronomers.

I think that Carl has done a wonderful job and that people really appreciate and enjoy his programs a lot and that he brought a lot of people very close to being interested in what goes on at telescopes and the interpretation of the results from telescopes.
I think he's done a very good job for it.
That's a very general question.
Do you think that all the new results that have come out on
solar system objects in the last 30 years have affected the public's ideas to any extent?
Talking about the public that reads, for example.
Well, I mean, yes.
I mean, it helps by knowing more about, well, by knowing, for example, that there's not life on Mars, but that we have looked and that there was a possibility and, well, it didn't pan out.
and just the general intellectual excitement of thinking about something that's nearby.
I think people don't relate to stars.
My personal opinion, the general public doesn't relate to things that are far away.
They always want to know, well, how does this affect me?
If you tell them what you do and that you study astronomy or planets, they say eventually their question is, aside from polite questions,
A lot of people, the bulk of people in the United States say, well, really, how does this affect me and why should I be supporting it?
That's what they think deep down inside.
And if it's something that can relate to a person, like searching for life or looking at other planetary surfaces that are like the Earth.
Or deflecting killer asteroids.
Or deflecting killer asteroids.
Or preventing the ozone hole from growing or the greenhouse.
Well, yes.
Now, that's something that comes incredibly close to home.

Well, it used to be that people would talk about, or I would say things like, it's of interest to study other planets, like Venus and Mars, because they tell you something about the Earth, because they're very similar, and that we ought to make these comparative studies.
And those are sort of vague, generalized arguments that I don't think the general public would buy.
But if you discover all of a sudden that the ozone is disappearing over the South Pole, and that it might very well start disappearing over the North Pole,

by the year 2000, and that this work has been done by people who really were all planetary astronomers, well, almost all planetary astronomers at one time in their life, then maybe the virtue of what people had said before, that you should study these other systems, starts to come home.
Personal question here.
Now, I can recall you and Matt and you and I and Andy and all these fights about your Pepsios data.
What ever went on with all that?
Well, the key thing that sticks in my mind about Pepsios is that we did a
a mind-stretching experiment with it, which was to measure wind velocities on Venus.
This was a suggestion that was brought to us by Mike Belton one time when Mike and Don Hunton came up to visit the Pepsios on Mount Hopkins.
And they looked at this wonderful instrument and said, gee, you can measure wind velocities on Venus.
And we said, oh, we can?
We had been looking at carbon dioxide lines
in the upper atmosphere of Venus cloud tops.
And then we realized that, yes, of course they're bright.
This is a wonderful experiment.
And Nat and I worked on this for several years.

We worked very hard to try and make sure that there were not any instrumental biases, because what we were looking for was a very tiny shift in the wavelength of a spectral line formed in the atmosphere of Venus from sunlight.
The sunlight bounced off the top of the atmosphere of Venus.
Some of it was absorbed in a CO2 line.
And if the atmosphere was moving, if there were winds or velocities from mass motions in the atmosphere, you would see a small Doppler shift.
The Doppler shift would translate into a wavelength shift that you could measure on Earth.

So we measured Doppler shifts of these spectral lines at various places on the planet so that you could compare the light that you saw reflected from the limb with the light reflected from the terminator and see if there was a wavelength shift.
And if there was a wavelength shift, you could attribute that to a rotational velocity of the upper atmosphere.

And we observed this for several years when Venus was on different sides of the sun, in different configurations, under different circumstances, and measured what I am convinced is a very good measurement of 100 meter per second winds in the upper atmosphere of Venus.
And we published that paper.
There was...

Well, this is not my favorite story, but there was skepticism, mostly, from our good friend Andy Young, who took it upon himself to decide that there were a lot of instrumental effects in this complicated instrument that could have caused these winds to appear to be shifting when, in fact, they weren't.
I thought that I had taken out all of these effects by calibration and repeated measurements

uh... and uh... was convinced that he was wrong but we invited him up and he came up and worked on the mountain top with us for a week or so one time the results unfortunately were inconclusive we were not able to make experiments which showed that the instrument did have biases in it but we certainly were able to make the instrument produce biased results by pushing hard enough which i knew that you could do these were not the circumstances under which the wind velocities were measured

The outcome of that was, I believe, that... And this I'm not sure about because I don't have it documented, but I do believe that Andy spoke against these results to a number of people and said they can't possibly be measuring wind velocities there.
This is a figment of their imagination or whatever.
The instrument is full of biases.
And...
essentially caused these results not to be widely quoted.

I still, to this day, am absolutely convinced that we did take out the biases and that we could see these effects and that we did measure 100 meter per second winds and that there was absolutely nothing wrong with the measurements.
But I think it's a very unfortunate thing.
Well, for me at least, it's personally unfortunate that Andy felt so strongly about this that he went around and told people that these results were suspect.

And in fact, I remember clearly from one committee meeting that was held to try and summarize the results of the Venus upper atmosphere, I had a call one day from somebody who was responsible for writing up these results.

uh... results uh... jerry schubert and uh... he said you know that you know we're not gonna mention these results because uh... we think that they were contaminated or flawed or something like that and it was a result of uh... andy's lobbying i believe i i said the same thing to him but uh... you know i uh... what can you do you published your results so that people could then take a crack at them
But the results were never critiqued in a published paper.
There is absolutely no publication that I'm aware of that said, look, if you interpret the results this way or that way, they turn out to be wrong.
I'm going to consider you still a planetary astronomer because you are looking at the atmosphere of a planet, although we happen to live on it.
But still, I always print Earth with a capital E, not a small e, because it's like Mars.
How would you describe the current state of planetary astronomy?
Growing, shrinking, hanging in there, whatever?
You mean including the Earth or not including the Earth?
Both ways.
If you include the Earth, planetary astronomy is doing wonderfully because there's a lot of effort and interest in trying to find out what's going on with the Earth's atmosphere.
If you exclude the Earth, I think there's a terrible problem.
There's very little going on in planetary astronomy that I'm aware of.
They're shutting off the Venus.
surface Venus radar machine, and the only instrument that's going to be built now is going out to Pluto, which barely qualifies as a planet.
But as far as the Earth is concerned, the state of research is very exciting because we have these two problems that are clearly in the public mind.
One is of the buildup of carbon dioxide and the increasing temperature of the Earth, which has been advocated and promoted most strongly by
a former planetary person, Jim Hansen, at Goddard, whatever it is in New York City.
It's Goddard in New York.
And I happen to think Jim is right.
I remember Jim's original work in looking at the atmosphere of Venus and discovering from
inverting calculations that the particles in the stratosphere of Venus had to be spherical globs with an index of refraction of one point something, something, something, which was an absolute.
Or three.
You know this problem, too.
And just to diverge for a second, I remember this result so clearly.
I thought, this is astonishing.
How could he possibly say that nothing in nature is ideal like that?
That's a physicist idealization.
But he said that this is really the way it was.
And I remember we had a graduate student.
And I put the graduate student to this problem of saying, look, here's the handbook of chemistry and physics.
Why don't you look up all the substances that have index of refraction in this range and see what that could possibly be?
And the student came back and he said, well, there's sulfuric acid and there's other stuff.
And we sort of chuckled and said, well, obviously,
Very uninformed comment of ours.
Obviously, these clouds could not be made out of sulfuric acid particles, and sort of dropped it at that point.
And months and a year later, this was really taken up seriously.
I guess that was Louise Young that came up with that.
Louise Young commented on it.
Jeffrey Sill, you were involved, I think.
Yeah, yeah.
And so a number of people came up with it, but it was...
It was a major failure on my part not to follow that up vigorously after that because it was a very interesting result.
What influence has the private sector had on planetary astronomy?
Well, we actually...
have been funded by private companies to do some research, in particular on the Earth's atmosphere.
In this case, this was after I had switched from looking at planets to looking at the Earth's atmosphere.
But if you count the Earth then, the Chemical Manufacturers Association in the early 80s

funded us for a number of years in parallel with NASA to augment our NASA funding, which was not quite enough to do what we would like to have done, to look at problems in the stratosphere of the Earth that were basically things that resulted from chemicals that would be put into the Earth.
This was in the early days of realizing that it was before there was an ozone problem, quite clearly.

there were issues of looking at hydrochloric acid, hydrofluoric acid, and other things that are, well, hydrochloric acid, the HCL, is generated mostly by freons that come from the chemicals that are manufactured by,
manufactured for aerosol use.
And we had a good relationship with the CMA in sponsoring some of our research.

And again, just as with NASA, they gave us the money, we did the work that we promised to do, but they never came back and insisted that we do something different or insisted on reviewing our results before they were published.
They were quite even-handed and
scholarly about it.
So we did have some private research funding, interestingly.
Did you ever have any funding from the Department of Defense?
Not for doing, no.
We had no Defense Department funding for doing planetary work.
To switch to a different topic, there was quite a bit of thought 20 years ago as to whether there ought to be a separate planetary sub
in the American Astronomical Society.
Now, of course, there is a division for planetary studies.
Do you think that was a good idea?

Oh, I think it's an excellent idea to have the planetary division, because if you look at the meeting, look at the abstracts for the meetings, they have grown enormously over the years, and there's a lot of really interesting material.
Unfortunately, I haven't been to a DPS meeting for maybe 10 years.
Do you think that the majority of planetary astronomers are putting it the other way, the
How much connection is there between people who work on the planets and people who work on stars and galaxies?
For example, here at CFA.
Oh, how much connection is there?
I mean, how do people know what the other people are doing?
Oh.
Or do they care?
Very little, I would say.
Very little.
Yeah.
I think that that's, I mean, people are,
I don't think that there's a whole lot of cross-fertilization or cross-interest, really.
I wanted to ask you about Icarus.
Icarus is now the premier journal for planetary astronomy.
And 20 or 30 years ago, it was distinctly second class.
How do you think it rates now against the FJ?
Well, Icarus certainly is a much larger and, I guess I would say, more carefully refereed and believable journal than it used to be.
The APJ, of course, has an incredibly high standard.
So I think it's getting up close there.
But in the early days, when a lot of not a lot was, well, it's surprising because, I mean, there's always not a lot known about stars.
There's also not a lot known about planets.
But a lot of the planetary papers, I think, were very speculative.
And so they weren't considered to be solid science.
But if you think about it, a lot of the papers on stars and galaxies are equally speculative or more so.
Or cosmology.
But they're printed in a format that makes them look very so-called scientific, I suppose.
Do you think the idea of having a journal like Icarus is a good one?
Oh, absolutely.

I mean, a specialized journal, well, it's hardly even specialized, but a journal where you can go and find things that are relevant to a field or you can pick it up and you can say, okay, I want to know what's going on in planetary astronomy these days.
You know where to go and pick it up and leaf through it.
I don't think there's hardly any.
I can't remember the last article that I saw in the AppJ that was a planetary journal.
We've published planetary articles in the AppJ, but I don't know if anybody ever read them.
It is a self-evident fact that radio astronomers are a less stuffy bunch than optical astronomers, and they have their own poker game that AAS means and all that sort of stuff.
Do you think that planetary astronomers, as a group, are less pompous and stuffy than stellar and galactic and cosmological astronomers?
Oh, I can't answer a question like that.
I have many friends in both areas.
I don't think that any of them are really particularly stuffy.
